titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Tuesday 1. August 1826. I had engaged to meet Mr Quincy between nine and ten this morning at Dedham; but while at breakfast I received a budget of despatches and Letters which occupied necessarily more than an hour, and Mr Joseph M. Sprague of Salem came to visit me, by which I was so detained that it was past ten before I arrived. My Son George went with me—I found Mr Quincy and Mr Thomas Greenleaf there— We attended at the Probate Court, before judge Robbins who read the Will in open Court, and administered to Mr Greenleaf the Oath, as a witness to its execution— The Probate Bond was then sealed and signed by Mr Quincy, my Son George and me; but by an accidental mistake, Mr Quincy’s eldest Son Josiah, not being present, the final execution of the Bond, and that of the other Bond, as Trustees of the bequests to my brother and his family, were postponed until the Court to be held next Tuesday at Quincy— There was a Mr Bugbee present in Court, who signed the Bond as a Witness, and there were three women there upon business of their own. I then came with George into Boston, and found my Son John, and my brother’s Son Thomas B. at Hamilton’s Exchange Hotel, where we dined— At 2. we proceeded to Charlestown, and were met at the Bridge by one of the Marshals of the day, who conducted us to the House of Dr Thomson, the Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements— Here a small number of the Citizens were introduced to me among whom several had been at the Bunker-Hill Battle, and sufferers by the conflagration of Charlestown— Dr Thompson’s father was one. After a handsome collation we walked to the Town Hall, where a great crowd of Citizens had assembled. Dr Thomson announced me to them, and said he should proceed to introduce each of them individually to me. The Hall was however so full that this was impracticable. A few near me were introduced, and then the Doctor observed that he should dispense with any further personal introductions— We proceeded then through a heavy-shower of rain to the meeting house, where an opening prayer was made by Mr Fay; an Eulogy upon John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, was delivered by Mr Edward Everett, and a concluding prayer by Mr Walker—with occasional anthems and dirges— We returned to Dr Thomson’s to Coffee, where his Lady and about forty others were introduced to me— Governor Lincoln was present at these Solemnities— I returned to Boston, and after an hour at Mrs S. A. Otis’s, came to lodge at the Exchange— Found Dr Huntt here. The Sheriff C. P. Sumner came to say the Governor would receive me tomorrow at the Council Chamber.

2. IV:30. Wrote a Letter to my wife, to be sent by Dr. Huntt— At 7. this morning two of the members of the Committee of Arrangements of the young Men, came to the Hotel, and I went with them to the State-House where I was received by Governor Lincoln at the Council Chamber— We passed thence into the Senate Chamber, where a small number of persons were introduced to me; and we walked in procession to the Meeting in Chauncy Place, where an Eulogy upon John Adams and Thomas Jefferson was delivered by Samuel L. Knapp, with opening and concluding prayers by Mr Greenwood, a dirge and Anthem were also performed by a small choir of singers— The procession was escorted to church, by the company of City Guards in which my Son George is a Lieutenant— He was however not with them on this occasion but with us— The services were completed about ten O’Clock— I returned to the Hotel accompanied by Messrs.Loring and Sampson, two of the members of the Committee of Arrangements— At 11. I went again to the Senate Chamber in the State House; where the Governor and Lieutenant Governor Thomas L. Winthrop, were with the Mayor, and authorities of the City were assembled, and when we went in procession to Faneuil Hall, and heard an Eulogy upon John Adams and Thomas Jefferson by Mr Daniel Webster— The prayers were performed by Charles Lowell— There was a funeral symphony Anthem and Dirge— The Streets from the State House to the Hall were thronged with a greater concourse of People than I ever witnessed in Boston— The Hall itself was crowded to the utmost of its capacity. Mr Webster was about two hours and a half in delivering his discourse, during which attention held the whole Assembly mute. He returned with us to the Hotel, and thence to his own home. The Governor also paid me a visit accompanied by his Aids—Lieutenant Colonels Josiah Quincy junr. and John B. Davis. He was to return this afternoon to Worcester, but said he would meet me next week on Thursday at Salem— I dined with my brother, his son T. B. and my Sons George and John, at Lieutenant Governor Winthrop’s. Met there Mr Charles Lowell, David Searsthree Sons and one daughter of Mr Winthrop, and a young Lady named Palmer— In the Evening I returned to Quincy with my Son George— My brother, his wife and daughter Abigail, Louisa C. Smith—Mrs Susan B. Clarke, my Son John, and my brother’s Son, T. B. were all present at the performances in Faneuil Hall, and all returned this Evening to Quincy. Harriet Welsh returned yesterday to Boston; and declined going with us again to Quincy this Evening— I have received high, though melancholy gratification from these performances, but found myself much, too much overcome with fatigue— The weather this day was fine, but warm.
3. III:30. A Night of broken rest.

A person, who said his name was Dunbar, and that he belonged to Scituate came this morning before Breakfast; merely for the curiosity of seeing the President of the United States— At 11. I bathed at Mr. Greenleaf’s wharf with my Sons George and John— We dined shortly after noon— Mrs James H. Foster, and her Son William called, and he brought me a large bundle of Letters and despatches, which I had then barely time to open— I went with all the family, to Coll. Minot Thayer’s at Braintree— There, after, about two hundred citizens of the neighbouring towns had been introduced to me, we went in procession to Mr Perkins’s Meeting House, where an Eulogy was to be delivered upon John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, by the Revd.Mr Storrs, Minister of the first Church in Braintree— The opening Prayer was made by Mr Perkins— The concluding Prayer, by Mr Hitchcock of Randolph. There was the Anthem “Child of Mortality,” and a Dirge, written by Mrs Fyfield a Lady of Weymouth, once Miss Bond— The Eulogy of Mr Storrs, was professionally made a Religious discourse—a Sermon from Psalm 82.6—and 7. “I have said, ye are Gods:— But ye shall die like Men”— Mr Storrs disclaimed Eulogy or panegyric, but bore a warm and affectionate testimony to my father’s character— After the ceremonies were over we returned for a few minutes to Coll. Thayer’s, and I thence went with Louisa Smith, Abigail and T. B. Adams, and my two Sons, and took coffee at Mr Cotton Tufts’s— There we met his Son Quincy Tufts—his daughters Mrs Tarbell, Susan and Mercy—Mrs Bond and Mrs Fyfield—Mr and Mrs Brooks of Hingham—Mr Whitney his Son and daughter, and Mr T. Greenleaf of Quincy and his two daughters— We returned home about the dusk of the Evening— Among the persons introduced to me this afternoon at Coll. Thayer’s was my Cousin John Adams of Randolph. Son of my father’s brother Elihu— He said it was about fifty years since he had seen me— His Son John was with him. About three years since, I went with my father, to his house at Randolph to see him, but he was then absent at Abington— We saw his Son— Mr Tufts gave me for perusal a small bundle of papers containing a correspondence between his father Dr Tufts, and my father, and mother when they were in Europe.
4. IV:15.— Sun rose 4:51.

Mr Charles Jeremiah Adams of Dorchester came on a morning visit with a boy nine or ten years of age, his Son— He is himself the Son of the late Elijah Adams of Medfield— A Mr Robert Milton, also called from Braintree; a revolutionary Soldier— A Pensioner under the Act of 1818 but struck from the List in consequence of the Act of 1820. He brought with him a piece of a Ramrod which he says was accidentally shot through his body, thirty-six years ago, by a Militia Soldier at a parade. It confined him for three years and has much disabled him ever since— He is anxious to obtain a restoration of his pension, and proposes to petition Congress, which I encouraged him to do— I bathed at the wharf with my Sons at Noon; but remained not more than ten minutes in the water— As we were about rising from dinner there came four Penobscot Indians, named Lewis NewellJohn Clew, Swassen Dana—and Saul Souzo— The first, a man as he said 67 years of age; the last a boy of about 14. The pretence of their visit was to see their father the President of the United States— Their real object to beg, which they did with great assiduity, and address— They live, the old man told me, about twelve miles from Bangor, on Penobscot River, and are wandering about the Country; collecting what they can obtain— They brought me a Letter of recommendation from Mr Fenwick the Roman Catholic Bishop of Boston— Mr John Marston, with his two daughters, Louisa and and Miss Randall paid us an evening visit— Josiah Adams the younger was here this Morning, and I directed him to make me three wooden Chests, with good locks for the preservation of Papers— George is making a copy of my father’s Will, in a book, wherein I propose that a Record of the proceedings of the Executors under it shall be kept— Some questions with respect to the operation upon my father’s Will of the subsequent disposal by him of a part of the Estate bequeathed by him in it, make it necessary to proceed with the utmost caution, and full deliberation— I received this afternoon Letters, from my wife and my Son Charles, written the first instt. from New-York— They were going in a day or two to Mr De Wint’s, and thence to the Springs at Lebanon in that State— The Letters and despatches that I am daily receiving accumulate, and run me into arrears, which I fear I shall never retrieve.
5. IV.— Sirius not visible.

I received again many Letters and despatches— Answered several of them; and from the rising hour till Noon, with half an hour’s interruption for breakfast was constantly occupied in writing— Examined in part a Statute of the Commonwealth; to regulate the Jurisdiction, and proceedings of the Courts of Probate—of 24. Feby 1818. to which there is an additional Act of 12. Feby 1821— Mr Peter C. Brooks, and Mr Edward Everett came on a morning visit— Bathed at the wharf with my two Sons, and three Sons of my brother— Mr Marston and Miss A. Harrod dined here— After dinner Mrs Briesler with were here— There came two Ladies from Boston; one elderly; the other young and handsome— The latter delivered to me a Letter, signed Charles Parsons, who she said was her father—soliciting my influence with the Collector of the Customs at Boston, to obtain some office in that Department for him— The young Lady urged his suit with much eloquence, and not without tears. I promised to speak of her father to the Collector— My Son John went into Boston this afternoon with T. B. Adams jr. and returned this Evening— I made extracts from the Books of Parish Records, lent me by Mr Whitney— I also read this day the papers lent me, by Mr Tufts. They are Letters from my father and mother to Dr Tufts from 1784 when my Mother went to Europe, till her return home with him in 1788—during this period Dr Tufts was my fathers Agent for his private affairs: and he was also a Senator for the County of Suffolk in the Legislature of the Commonwealth— There are copies of some of the Doctor’s Letters in answer to those of my Parents— The correspondence is upon affairs public and private, and to my recollections deeply interesting. There is with it, one Letter from my Sister, relating to an important incident in her life; and the Doctors Answer— The family concerns relate also to my brothers and myself, as we then were in child hood and in youth, at School, and at College— This Evening with George, I viewed the successive appearances of the Stars of the first and second magnitude, as the darkness of Night came on— But at the close of the day I am not satisfied with the manner in which it has been employed— I have signed 450 Land-grants, at Crawfordsville, Indiana, sent me by G. Graham, three Proclamations for Sales of Lands, and 14. Commissions.

Heard Mr Whitney this morning from John 4:34. “Jesus saith unto them, My meat is to do the will of him that sent me, and to finish his work.” It was the communion day, and gave me occasion to reflect that having reached my sixtieth year, I am yet not a member of any Christian Church— As this is the Church to which my fathers have belonged, from its foundation; little less than two hundred years, I have perhaps too long neglected to join it— After dinner, I attended with George, at the Episcopal Church, and heard Mr Cutler from Exodus 20.13. “Thou shalt not kill.” It was one of a Series of discourses which he is preaching from the ten Commandments— This Society is small, but they make up in zeal, what they lack in numbers— The house was well filled.— Returning home, we stopped at the grave-yard, and found the Tomb where my Parents repose duly repaired— We found the Tombstones of William Thompson the first Minister of the Church— Of Henry and Margery Flynt, and of Judith Reiner, Sister to my Ancestor Daniel Quincy— I examined also this day the papers relating to the Mount Wollaston farm; by which I find that it was purchased by several conveyances from 1639 to 1643. from William Coddington by William Tynge, a Merchant of Boston— From him it descended to his daughter Anna, who married Thomas Sheppard of Charlestown— They had a daughter Anna who married first, my ancestor Daniel Quincy, and after his death, the Revd. Moses Fiske— In 1709. Anna Sheppard widow, by Will, devised the farm to her grandson John Quincy, son of her daughter Anna, and of Daniel Quincy, and designated in the Will as a student at Harvard College— He had taken his first degree there in 1708— John Quincy devised the Estate to his only Son, Norton, who devised it in three equal parts to the children of his three Sisters— Elizabeth Smith, Anna Thaxter, and Lucy Tufts— My Mother as one of the daughters of Elizabeth Smith thus received a portion of the Estate, and all the other portions were purchased by my father— He and my Mother in August 1803. conveyed to me, her portion in trust for them and the survivor of them during their lives, remainder to me in fee— And in 1819. my father conveyed to me the whole Estate in fee, upon my executing a Bond to him to pay him a thousand dollars a year during his life; the payments of which have accordingly been made— I also looked into some old papers of my father and found fragments of Journals as early as 1756 at Worcester: but I have now no time to examine or arrange them.

Day passed without interruption of visitors, except a person by the name of Nicholson who came from Boston, and applied to my brother, soliciting an appointment as a Light-House keeper in the County of Barnstable. George went into Boston this morning, and returned at Night— I was much occupied in perusing all the remainder of the papers of my Great-grandfather John Quincy, which were delivered to me with the Mount Wollaston Estate, and which I had never before had time to examine. They relate principally to Town and Parish proceedings; but there are also several deeds and other documents relating to the Affairs of William Tynge—and of Thomas Shepard— An inventory of William Tynge’s Estate taken after his decease is almost illegible, as are several other Papers. I found in Mather’s Magnalia, accounts of three Thomas Shepards—the first Book 3. chap. 5. born 5. Novr. 1605. arrived at Boston 3. Octr. 1635. was Minister at Cambridge, and died 25. August 1649— The second Book 4. Ch. 4. Son of the former, born in 1635. graduated at Harvard College 1653. and died 22. Decr 1677. He was Minister at Charlestown, and married Anna daughter of William Tynge— Their daughter Anna married Daniel Quincy. The third. Book 4. ch. 9— Son of the second was born 5. July 1658. graduated 1673. succeeded his father as Minister of Charlestown in 1680. and died 7. June 1685— I wrote several Letters, and after dinner had a second long conversation with my brother with regard to his future intentions—concerning himself and his family— I told him that I should probably take this place upon the Conditions prescribed by the Will, and paying the whole sum required by it although a very valuable portion of it has been otherwise disposed of by my father since the devise was made—and I made him the offer that he should continue to reside here with his family, until the next Spring, and if he chooses, until I shall myself be dismissed from public life; when my intention is to come and reside here myself— The terms I assured him, upon which he should have the house would be as easy to himself as he could obtain by residing elsewhere— He did not chuse to take charge of the farm but seemed not disinclined to keep the house, and asked me to speak with his wife— It will also be necessary to consult Louisa Smith and Mrs Clarke— He expressed a wish that the places at Braintree and at Medford, mortgaged by him to me should be sold,—to pay as far as they would go his debt to me: but I told him I should not incumber the bequests of my father to him, with that debt— That I should propose, that the Interest of the bequests to him and his family, should be paid to him quarterly, for the support of his family, till it should be necessary to pay the principal of the devise to each of his children as they shall come of age. Bathed at the wharf, before dinner with John and T. B. A. jr

I attended with my Son George, the Court of the Judge of Probate this morning— Mr Quincy and his Son Josiah came, and the Execution of the bond was completed, and we received 1—The probate of the Will— 2. At my request a Copy of the Bond. 3. An order to post and publish our appointment as Executors—which order is to be returned to the Probate Office within seven Months. 4. A Warrant to Daniel Greenleaf, Josiah Bass, and Josiah Adams, as Appraisers, and to take the Inventory of the Estate. We posted up the notification of our Appointment, at French’s tavern— Mr Haven the Register of Probate, witnessed the Execution of the Bond by Josiah Quincy jr Mr Quincy came home with me, and we had some conversation, concerning the bequest to me of the homestead at this place— The main question is whether the devise is entirely revoked, by the subsequent alienation of a part of the Estate, or whether I can still take the remnant of the farm, by paying the sum annexed as the condition to my taking the whole— Mr Quincy had no doubt that I may; but my brother has doubts, and Mr Quincy thought it might be proper to take an opinion of a Lawyer, upon the Question— He mentioned Judge Jackson. I said I should wish first to take the opinion of the judge, and if he should have no doubt, I would act upon his opinion— If he doubted, we might take the opinion of Judge Jackson— I wrote a circular, to be sent with copies of the Will, to W. S. Smith, J. A. Smith, Mrs. De Wint, and Mrs Johnson of Utica— I also wrote four questions upon the Will, signed by myself, and after dinner took them up to the judge, requesting his decision upon them— He said he would call on his way home in the Evening, and answer them— I walked round by Edward Miller’s. The judge called late in the Evening, and repeated the opinion, that the devise to me was so far valid that I might take the Estate as now remaining, on the condition of paying the sum at which my father had estimated it with the 103 acres— But as I told him that I had read some authorities in the Law-Books, which left it doubtful, he said he would take further time for advisement and consult Swinburn, the best authority in such cases— I mentioned to him the grounds of my difficulties, and said I was prepared to take the place, as reduced by the last conveyances and pay for it the whole sum of ten thousand dollars required by the Will— But to proceed with safety I wished to have a decree to sanction the proceeding— Mr Daniel Greenleaf called this afternoon; said he was going to Boston to-morrow; and proposed stopping to engage Mr Withington, the Surveyor, to make the Surveys of the real Estate— I postponed however an immediate decision— Withington made the Survey of the Lands given to the Town.
9. IV:15. Beclouded.

Judge Robbins, inadvertently left last Evening some of his papers, on the table, and I rode over to his house at Milton this morning, with George, and returned them to him— We called also at Mr D. Greenleaf’s and left word that I wished him to ask Mr Withington the Surveyor, to come on Saturday or Monday next, to commence the Survey of the real Estate. As we passed by the House of Captain Josiah Bass we met him in the road and I informed him of his appointment by the Judge of Probate as one of the Appraisers, and he accepted— We returned home to Breakfast. T. B. Adams jr. with his Sister Abigail, Mrs Clarke and her Daughter Susan went to Scituate, on a visit to Mrs Cushing, and returned this Evening. Mr and Mrs Cruft returning to Boston, from a ride to Hanover, called for a few minutes in the forenoon, and General William H. Sumner, adjutant General of this Commonwealth, came to converse with me upon his plans for the improvement of the Militia System of the United States, and dined with us— He has great earnestness and anxiety upon the subject, and fears that unless Congress shall soon establish a more efficient system, it will go altogether into decay, and ruin— Among the principal improvements which he deems essential is the appointment of an Adjutant General of the United States for the Militia— He complained that the Secretary of War had not treated his communications with so much respect, as was due to them, and he read me Letters from General Scott and General Bernard, highly approving the project of an Adjutant General of the Union for the Militia. General Sumner does not concur with General Macomb, or with General Cadwalader in their Militia theories, and considers it rather as a civil Institution than as an Army— There was brought me this afternoon an old folio manuscript Volume, containing Records of the Town of Braintree from 1687 to 1757— Among the entries I find that the Court of Justices in 1688 appointed Joseph Adams junr. (my father’s grandfather) a Constable for the Town of Braintree that year— The same Joseph Adams signs as the first of the Select-men in 1717— The same year 24. Feby. is an entry of £6. paid to Major John Quincy for service as Representative—and on 5. Jany 1718. an order to pay him five Pounds money in full for his serving as Representative in the year 1717— This Book, and a stroll in the Garden and Orchard with George, this forenoon; to gether with General Sumner’s visit swallowed up the day. Public business deferred.
10. IV. Beclouded.

As has repeatedly happened during my present absence from the seat of Government, a large mass of Letters and despatches came upon me just as I was about to leave home— I was obliged to abandon them for the moment, and immediately after Breakfast rode with George into Boston. I called at Mr Stuart the Painter’s but he was not at home. I then went to Mr James H. Foster’s whom I saw, with his family— I found at his house two volumes of my Books, which W. S. Shaw had taken many years since from the Athenaeum, and left in a closet at Mr Foster’s— At the Exchange Hotel, I found a Carriage waiting for us, and several more Letters and Despatches. We proceeded to Salem, and went directly to Mr N. Silsbee’s— Governor Lincoln soon after came in with his Aids, Coll. Quincy and Davis— A company of about twenty persons successively assembled, and after a Collation which was a dinner the Marshals of the day, and several persons from the adjoining towns of Danvers, Beverley, Gloucester and Marblehead were introduced to me, and a procession was formed on the Square, whence we marched escorted by a Company of Salem Cadets to the North Church— The ceremonies there were similar to those I had five times witnessed last week— An introductory Prayer by Mr. Coleman— A concluding Prayer by Mr Williams— An Eulogy upon John Adams and Thomas Jefferson by Joseph E. Sprague— A Voluntary upon the Organ, a Hymn, an Anthem and a Dirge, by the Choir, were the Musical performances, and the final Benediction was pronounced by Dr Prince— We then repaired to Mr B. W. Crowninshield’s and dined— Before dinner, a Revolutionary Sail maker named Pearce, from Cape-Ann, came to me, complaining that he had been on the Pension List of 1818. and was afterwards stricken from it— He was desirous of having it restored, to which I assured him, I would contribute as far as might be in my power. Mr Webster and Mr Everett called with Judge Story at Mr Crowninshield’s, but did not remain to dine. In the Evening, I returned with Mr Silsbee to his house, with George to pass the Night— Mrs Silsbee was below in the Morning, but in the Evening was confined to her Chamber— Coll. B. Pickman, and several other persons of my acquaintance here were not present at the ceremonies of the day—having declined to take part in them— The weather was threatening rain the whole day; but there was very little sprinkling, till after we were housed for the Night— It then came in copious Showers.
11. V:30.— Rain all Night.— Salem— Boston.

Governor Lincoln and his Aids breakfasted with us at Mr Silsbee’s. I had previously been occupied with the Letters and papers received yesterday Morning at Boston and which I had taken with me. After Breakfast, about ten we left Salem, and alighted at the Exchange Hotel, in Boston, with rain scarcely intermitted, all the way— I signed a batch of Land-grants and 16. Virginia Military Warrants received from the General Land-Office, and wrote an Answer to the Resolutions of a Meeting of Citizens held at Charleston S.C. the 27th. of last Month— Mr Joseph Hall called and set with me till four, when I went with George and dined at Mr Webster’s. Governor Lincoln, and a Company of twenty other Gentlemen were there. No Ladies except Mrs Webster— Coll. T. H. Perkins just returned from England, was of the company— After dinner, I had a private Conversation with the Governor, in which I urged him, should the health of Mr Mills which is said to be very bad, induce him to decline a re-election, to accept from the Legislature, an election, which I believed they would offer him to a seat in the Senate of the United States— He said he had just before leaving Worcester seen Mr Mills whose health was improving; but with regard to the proposition that he should go to the Senate, spoke doubtfully— Observed he had a family to educate— That his present situation was liable to the sudden and unforeseen changes of popular Sentiment— Spoke of the opposition started against him at his last election— Of the religious dissensions fermenting in the State, and of a prevailing inclination in his mind to relinquish public Life, and return to the practice of the Law— I replied that if that was his intention, a Seat in the Senate would be an easy and honourable descent from the Chair to the Bar—which hitherto no Governor of Massachusetts had made. That in my wish to see him in the Senate, I looked to a period beyond that of my own continuance in the public service—to a field more extensive for the exercise of his Talents, than any one State could afford; to the future character and influence of New-England in the Union— He said he was duly sensible to the confidence I had manifested in him by this Conversation, and would give it full and deliberate consideration— After he retired I remained and passed a pleasant Evening at Mr Webster’s— The rain prevented my returning as I had intended this Night to Quincy. Mr. Matthew St. Clair Clarke, Clerk of the House of Representatives U.S. came in after dinner— Leaves the City to-morrow— I returned to the Hotel between nine and ten.
12. V:15. Rain all Night— Boston. Quincy.

After Breakfast, I came in a Chaise with William out to Quincy; and arrived about Noon; somewhat annoyed by the rain, which continued with few and short intervals the whole day.— George remained in Boston, and came out this afternoon in the Stage— I returned to my occupations Public and private, interrupted by my excursion— Signed 75 Land-grants; answered E. Everett’s Letter upon the second of Cimon’s Hermae Inscriptions in Plutarch, and two Letters from N. G. Cleary. Charleston S.C—dipping also a little into Mather’s Magnalia, and a little into Hutchinson’s History. Mrs. Susan B. Clarke, daughter of my deceased brother Charles, and widow of Lieutenant Clarke of the Navy, from the death of my brother in 1801. with the interval of a year or two while she was married has always lived with my father, and been chiefly maintained by him, with her daughter Susan, now in her ninth year— She came this afternoon to ask my advice how she should dispose of herself the ensuing Winter— I told her that if I should take this place—as authorised by the Will, I had offered my brother the option of residing here the ensuing year, and even till I should come to reside here myself; and in that case she might remain here. This however she immediately declined, and said she had thoughts of going to board with Mr and Mrs Cutler, and of sending Susan to the Academy of the Misses Dana, at Cambridge— I found upon enquiring that this double expense would exceed the income of her property, both from that left her by her husband, and that which she will receive as one of the Devisees of my father— The Separation of herself from her daughter will necessarily much increase her expenses, and I did not perceive its necessity— Mr Cutler is the Minister of the Episcopal Church in this Town, and lives in the house of the late G. W. Apthorp— Mrs Clark has become much attached to that Church— I finally advised her before taking her determination to wait and see what the state of her income will be on the distribution of the proceeds of my father’s Estate— My entomology continues experimental; but my search of Forest Trees flags— Judge Davis gave me yesterday two Acorns from English Oaks, but they are nearly three years old— Several of our worms have nested themselves in Cocoons, and one of the family of seven which we found on a lime-leaf, this day cast off for the second time, his vesture; but this time without changing colour.
13. V. Rain

Heard Mr Bowes Whitney of Hingham, this morning from Proverbs 15.3. “The eyes of the Lord are in every place, beholding the evil and the good” and in the afternoon from Proverbs 30.8.9. “Remove far from me vanity and lies; give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with food convenient for me:— Lest I be full, and deny thee, and say, Who is the Lord? or lest I be poor, and steal, and take the name of my God in vain.” It rained almost without interruption the whole day. There were at Meeting less than forty persons in the morning, without a female or a singer— In the afternoon about fifty—one woman, and singers enough to make discord. I invited Mr Whitney home to dine with us, and took him to Mr Peter Whitney’s when the afternoon services were closed— John went to Mr Quincy’s, and obtained his signature to several papers relating to the Execution of my father’s Will— Mr Bowes Whitney, is an intelligent man and a sensible preacher but has not much conversation. He told me however some anecdotes, and among the rest one—of my father’s Cousin Zabdiel Adams, Minister of Lunenburg, who at the time when my father was President, complained to Mr Whitney’s Father; that he himself, had not made the Law his profession instead of preaching— For, said he, why should not I have been President of the United States as well as my Cousin John?— The Law might have carried Mr Zabdiel Adams to Congress—perhaps to the Senate of the United States; for he was a man of good Talents; and in this Country the Law is the natural profession of men, aspiring to political distinction. But in the notices which I have collected, from the Town records, from the few papers the preceding ages which have come to my hands, from Mather’s Magnalia, and Hutchinson’s History, and lastly from the Catalogue of Harvard College, I cannot overlook the difference of Fortune in Life, between those of my kindred, who were educated at Cambridge, and those deprived of that advantage— My father’s uncle Joseph was graduated at Harvard, and became an eminent Minister, at Newington, New Hampshire. If my Grandfather himself had received the same education, he would have been distinguished, either as a Clergyman or as a Lawyer.

lg.l: But knowledge to his eyes, her ample page
Rich with the spoils of Time, did ne’er enroll.

div.p: and the summit of his political elevation, was the Office of a Selectman of Braintree
14. V. Rain

The Governor of the State of Maine, Albion K. Parris called upon me this morning to make enquiries, respecting the present state of the negotiation with Great-Britain, concerning the boundary between that State, and the British Province of New-Brunswick— I told him that owing to the continued illness of Mr Rufus King, since his arrival in England, and his resignation which has been accepted, no progress had been made in the negotiation, since it was left unfinished by Mr Rush— But that Mr Gallatin had received particular Instructions on the subject, and had made him-self fully master of it, before he left this Country— That I was expecting daily to hear of his arrival in England, where he would immediately apply to the British Government to resume the Negotiation— Mr Parris spoke of the deep interest which his State had in the controversy; and although he expressed full confidence that the Government of the United States would consent to no stipulation injurious to the rights of the State, yet he said they were not without apprehensions that New-York might be willing to purchase Rouse’s point, at the expence of Maine— He manifested a wish to be furnished with copies of the arguments of the Agents and Reports of the Commissioners under the 5th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent, which we declined giving heretofore from an apprehension that a premature disclosure of them might operate unfavourably upon the Negotiation— I told him that their great bulk, was an obstacle to the furnishing of copies, but that they had been and would still be open to the inspection, and perusal of the Representatives and Senators from Maine in Congress, and would be equally so to the Governor of the State if present. He said he should retire from the Government of the State at the close of the present year, and gave me a cordial invitation to attend the Commencement at Bowdoin College, the first Wednesday in September—he also promised that if I would come, the visit should be as private and unceremonious as I could wish— Thomas B. Adams junr. who has been since last Thursday at Boston returned this afternoon. My Son John with Joseph H.my brother’s youngest Son, went and dined at Boston, and returned this Evening— I received a Letter from judge Cranch, enclosing one for his Sister Lucy Greenleaf, which I took to her. George walked with me. Mr J. Greenleaf was not at home. Two daughters of the late judge Dawes were there.— We had a short evening visit from Mr Marston. Rain with intervals the whole day. I was buried great part of it in Winthrop’s Journal, and a search for endless genealogies— Wrote three short Letters, and received several—
15. V. Rain.

A day without interruption, which I employed in signing Land-grants—answering Letters; copying the remnant of an old Deed upon parchment, being a distribution by Covenants of the Estate of William Ting, of Boston—Merchant, made on the 28th. of March 1661 after his decease, between Thomas Brattle and Elizabeth his wife Thomas Shepard and Anna his wife, Bethiah and Mercy Ting, dividing in equal parts the property between these four daughters of William Ting— It was Anna, the daughter of this Thomas and Anna Shepard, who married first my Ancestor Daniel Quinsey, and afterwards the Revd. Moses Fiske— And it was the Anna Shepard, whose name is subscribed to this Deed, who in 1709. bequeathed the Estate at Mount Wollaston, the portion assigned to her in the deed, to her grandson, John Quincy, my great Grandfather— The Deed is acknowledged on the day of its date before Humphrey Atherton; but does not appear to have been recorded— It is so defaced, that I have been obliged to leave several blanks in the copy; but the blanks could contain nothing material to the character of the contract— The portions of Bethiah and Mercy Ting, are also located at Braintree, and that of Elizabeth Brattle at Boston. William Ting appears never to have resided at Braintree, but on the town Records his brother Edward is named as a Magistrate who solemnized many marriages. William Ting’s name appears as a Captain of a Military company here; and Edmund Quincy the second, as successively a Lieutenant, Captain, Major, and Lieutenant Colonel. He was also a Justice of the Peace, and according to Hutchinson’s History, one of the members of the Council of Safety, in April 1689. chosen to administer the Government which had been taken by a popular Insurrection, from the hands of Sir Edmund Andros, the Governor appointed by James the Second— Of the first John Norton, I find an Account in Mather’s Magnalia Book 3. ch. 2. His Son, John Norton graduated at Harvard 1671. was Minister at Hingham and his daughter Elizabeth was the wife of my great grand-father John Quincy. Mrs Greenleaf says that Mary Norton, the wife of the Minister of Hingham, was before her marriage named Mason— There was rain fog and mist almost the whole of this day. I took a walk with George at the Dusk of Evening; but we were soon obliged to return.
16. V. Rain. Fog.

Kelleran was Master of a Vessel sailing from Portland in Maine— At Turk’s Island he refused to deposit his Register with Thomas Wynns, the consular Agent of the United States, on the plea that he was not recognized by the Government there as a Consul— On his return home he was prosecuted in the name of Wynns, before the U.S. District Court in Maine, and on the 4th. of December 1822 petitioned Mr Monroe for a remission of the penalty; and says he received no answer. He says also that a Letter was written to Mr Clay 30. Augt. 1825. requesting the Petition might be laid before the President— He brought me a copy of the Petition, with Letters of recommendation, from John Anderson the present, and Stephen Longfellow the last Representative of the District in Congress. He had been to New-York on his way to Washington, to see me, but finding I had passed him on the way, came back. He says the prosecution is still pending and that an order has recently been received from an Auditor (Pleasonton) to press for a judgment. That he has been unfortunate in some of his last voyages; and must go to Sea again— He said also that the penalty in other similar cases which occurred at the same time had been remitted— I had a very confused recollection of the case; but told him I would take information concerning it, at the Department of State, and would remit the penalty, if I could consistently with my duty— Mr Webster came with Mr Nicholas Biddle, President of the Bank U.S. on a morning visit— I wrote four short answers to Letters, and signed the packet of Land-grants last received from the Land Office, which with two days writing in this journal occupied the day— Towards the dusk of Evening, I walked with George to Mr Quincy’s, and found him with his family, except his Son Edmund, who is gone upon an excursion to visit the White Mountains. He had just come in from Boston, with his Son Coll. Josiah— His Son in Law Mr Greene, and wife, lately married were there, and his daughters Susan, Abigail and Sophia— Mr Quincy himself is still labouring under a severe and very pertinacious cough. On returning home I found a budget of Letters, with two new Packets of grants for Signature from the Land-Office. Among the Letters one from Mr John Welles, mentioning that his Lady and daughter had just arrived from Saratoga, where they had left my wife with improving health, and intending to come here.
17. V. Fog.

The first three of these persons are the Appraisers appointed by Judge Robbins, upon my father’s Estate— They came about nine this morning and after being sworn by my brother were employed till dinner time in taking the inventory of the furniture in the rooms and chambers, which they did not finish— Captain Bass was engaged elsewhere in the afternoon— And Mr Greenleaf to go home to dinner Deacon Adams dined with us— Mr Greenleaf came back after dinner, and with Deacon Adams, weighed all the Plate, amounting to 539 ounces, estimated at 1. dollar 12 1/2 cents an ounce— They are to come again and finish the appraisement of the personal Estate to-morrow. A Coll. Beneski, who told me that he was a native of France, born at Marseilles but of a Polish father, came and delivered me a Letter of Introduction from John Williams, Charge d’Affaires of the United States at Guatemala and he also delivered me a verbal message from the President of the Republic of Central America— He afterwards came with Aaron H. Palmer of New-York, and they exhibited to me, a contract made by Beneski for and in behalf of A. H. Palmer, and Company, with the Minister of the Treasury of Guatemala, and sanctioned by the Congress of that Republic for opening a water communication, through the lake of Nicaragua, from the Sea of the Antilles, to the Pacific Ocean— To this contract Coll. Beneski and Mr Palmer solicited the Protection and Patronage of the United States; which I assured them should be given so far as my personal influence and Constitutional Power could assure it— Mr Palmer said an Act of Incorporation of the Company would be indispensable; and a question was whether it should be obtained from the Legislature of New-York, or from Congress— I advised Mr Palmer to consult with the Representations and Senators from New-York on the Subject— I thought that Congress was the only proper authority to grant an act of Incorporation, for objects thus interesting to the whole Union, and even to the whole World— But I told them, Mr Clay purposed returning to Washington at the close of this or the beginning of the next Month, and advised them to address their future Communications to the Department of State. I was confined the whole day to the House by the weather.
18. IV. Fog. Rain—

Rising before day light, I took a solitary walk round by the episcopal Church, and the old Mill-Pond, about three Miles, with much benefit in Spirits from the Exercise. The Appraisers Daniel Greenleaf, Josiah Bass, and Josiah Adams, came again at eight this morning, and devoted the day to complete the appraisement of the personal Estate— They dined here, and resuming the work after dinner finished about Sunset— The journal of yesterday and of 9. July, with four short Letters was my work for the day— Its amusement was much abridged; and consisted in desultory reading— Mr George Blake, with a Son of Mr Webster, called here about Noon, on their way to Sandwich— Mr and Mrs Webster he told me preceded them on this tour yesterday. Mr Blake shewed me a Letter to him from Mrs Tudor, asking him to solicit my interposition with Mr Hopkinson, respecting a disagreement and separation, between Captain Charles Stuart, and his wife, who is Mrs Tudor’s daughter. Mrs Tudor’s chief concern now is for the two infant children, whom Captain Stuart insists upon taking under his own charge— Mrs Tudor wishes them to be placed under the care of Mr Gardner of Hallowell, Maine who married her other daughter, and with whom she is now residing— I told Mr Blake that the subject was an exceedingly delicate one; but that as a common friend to both parties, and especially from what was my father’s great attachment to the late judge Tudor, and his family, as well as my own, I would on my return towards Washington speak to Mr Hopkinson, and use my good offices as far as I should think judicious or proper; but as the facts of the case were almost wholly unknown to me, I know not what reply I should have to any answer Mr Hopkinson might give me. Blake knows much more of the facts than I do, and thinks Mrs Stuart has been only very indiscreet— I told him that the Office of Commissioner of the Navy had been offered by my direction to Stuart, and declined by him on account of these private misfortunes— At the dusk of Evening I took a ride in the Chaise with my Son John and my brother’s youngest Son Joseph. H— I find in the Massachusetts Historical Collections. Second Series Vol. 10. a List of the Representatives of the Town of Boston before the Revolution— Edmund Quincy, is one of the first three chosen 14. May 1634— William Ting, from 1639 to 1643 and 1646–7. and Edward Tyng 1661. and 1662.
19. IV:30— Fog— Mist— Cleared up. Wind Still East.

Penhallow is a young Man from New Hampshire, very desirous of obtaining a Midshipman’s Warrant— He says he has been several years an applicant and brought a recommendation of him very respectably signed— I advised him to write again to the Secretary of the Navy, and told him I would mention his name, when I should next write to the Secretary— John and William Foster, are sons of Phineas Foster who married a Sister of my brother’swife— They came out from Boston to visit their cousin. T. B—dined with us and returned in the Evening to Boston— Mrs Quincy with her daughters and Sophia paid us a morning visit— The weather having after ten days of Rain, Mist and fogs, partially cleared up, I bathed between Noon and one at Mr Greenleafs wharf with my two Sons— T. B. junr. and the two Foster’s. We found my brothers youngest Sons J. Q. and Joseph H. already there— George got bad scratching of both his legs, by careless stepping among the granite stones heaped on the wharf for transportation. I dove from the bridge. I wrote two pages of this book, signed 75 Land-grants, and answered four Letters, which is now my daily task and leaves me little time to indulge myself with genealogies, entomology, dendrology or Star-gazing, in all of which I find amusement. I received two Letters from my wife of the 13th and 14th. from Lebanon Springs, where she arrived last Sunday. This Evening, I rode in the chaise with my Son John and nephew John Quincy, to see Mr Bailey at Dorchester. We met him walking not far from his house, and he turned back— After passing an hour with him and Mrs Bailey, we returned over Neponset Bridge— We found on our returning home, Mrs Greenough, a Sister of my brother’s wife, and a boy of about twelve years of age, her Son, named John. Mr G. W. Beale was also here— I talked antiquities with Mrs Quincy— She says that the fact of the first Edmund Quincy’s having been one of the first Representatives of Boston is mentioned in her husband’s life of his father. But she was not aware of the Quincy descent from Margaret Flynt Sister of Edmund Quincy 2ds.first wife, and she asked me to write it down for her.
20. IV:30.— Saw Sirius— First clear morn of twelve.

Heard Dr Richmond of Dorchester in the morning from John 8.12. [“]Then spake Jesus again unto them, saying, I am the light of the World: he that followeth me, shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life”— In the afternoon from Psalm 24.3.4. “Who shall ascend into the hill of the Lord? and who shall stand in his holy place?— He that hath clean hands, and a pure heart: who hath not lifted up his Soul into vanity, nor sworn deceitfully.”— The matter of Dr Richmond’s discourses corresponds with his manner of delivery—rational and unimpassioned, their Style is plain, correct and not elegant or pretending— Dissertations of pure ethics drawn from the divine fountain of the Scriptures— He like all the preachers who exchange with Mr Whitney, is of the liberal class— He dined with us— A young man named Thomas Williston, of Boston, deaf and dumb came this afternoon and held a Conversation with me upon a Slate. He has been six years at the School in Hartford— I rode with John this evening in the Chaise, and paid a visit to Mrs Eustis, the widow of the late Governor— I found her very comfortably situated, with her mother and several of her Nephews about her. On returning home, I found Mr and Mrs Thomas Greenleaf, Mr and Mrs John Greenleaf, and Mr Marston, with the family— Mr Quincy and his Son in Law, Mr Green had been here while I was out— Mrs Greenough and her Son went away this Evening. I wrote to my wife, answering the two Letters received from her yesterday— The weather though fair is not settled. The heat of the day was oppressive, but the evening cool and pleasant. Our experiments with insects multiply— The large green worm, which I took from a Lime-tree on the Mount Wollaston Beach the 19th. of last Month, after feeding voraciously, nearly four weeks, and exhibiting several curious phenomena this day week buried himself in a thick spun nest under a large lime leaf. The green Sphinx found the 29th. of July, on a tree in the same row, last Tuesday cast off his whole Skin, and turned into a nymph, at first partly green but changed in twenty-four hours to a dingy black, without any protection of a nest. The family of seven found by my Son John, reduced to six by the escape of one have twice shed their entire skins, ravenously and incessantly feeding, and hitherto with little increase of their size— We have three or four caterpillars of various coloured garbs which have rolled themselves up in cocoons but none yet have come out with wings.
21. IV:30.— Beclouded. Clear— Rain

The Mayor of Boston came to enquire if I would attend the visitation of the Schools on Wednesday; and the subsequent dinner at Faneuil Hall— He said it would not be necessary for me to attend at more than two of the Schools, the High English and the Latin— I told him that I would come, and wished to attend at least one of the common Schools, as well as the two others— He said he would make his arrangements accordingly, and in the Evening I received a Letter from him, requesting me to attend at any time after half past ten, in Mason Street— Mr Withington the Surveyor came with Mr Daniel Greenleaf, about nine, and we commenced upon the Survey of my Father’s lands— We began with the Salt marsh, and took first what I shall call the Gull Island Lot, North of the Creek and opposite the Lime trees on the Mount-Wollaston Farm Beach— Our company consisted of Mr Withington the Surveyor, my brother, my Son George, Deacon Savile, Farrar, a hired workman of my father’s, and William Poet, the servant man, who came with me from Washington— The second Lot surveyed was mine, almost bounding upon the other, and called by my brother the Cherry-tree lot; from a large wild Cherry tree which formerly stood on the upland just without the fence bounding my Salt-marsh— The fence however does not surround the lot; one side of it being across the Marsh where no fence could stand— And here the line is in dispute with Captain Bracket the neighbouring owner— While we were there John Glover and Rufus Davis who reside in the neighbourhood came and marked the line upon which we were carrying the chain, as that which belonged to my lot— But Glover said Captain Bracket had lately been there; had forbidden any person from cutting the hay beyond the line claimed by him, and threatened to prosecute any one who should— The third lot surveyed was one called the eight Acre lot; approaching the beach upon which Mr Quincy’s Salt-works are erected, but bordering on upland of Jesse Fenno, and on a Creek dividing from land of Dr. Phipps. The Survey began and ended at a large single Lime tree standing on the upland of Fenno, just without the fence— Before we had finished this survey, at about one O’Clock there came a long and heavy Shower of Rain, which drove us home and suspended our field labours for the day— In the afternoon, I received a heavy Mail of Letters from Washington; the reading of which occupied me till near Sunset— I wrote but little— Towards evening I rode with John, and returned the visit of Mr Barney Smith at Milton— Found him at home; with his Son, Henry and two daughters of Mrs Russell. Mrs Smith was absent in Boston. Mr Bailey and a Mr Dexter of Boston were also there, engaged at a game of Chess. We came home about nine— I signed this Evening 150 Land-grants.
22. IV:30. Beclouded— Clear— Sultry.

There was an application of business to my Son, George, which required that he should be at Boston this Morning at ten O’Clock— I was unwilling to take him from any business of his own, and advised him to go— His mother has written repeatedly wishing him to go to her, before she returns to Washington, and I have advised him to go now, with his Cousin T. B. Adams jr. who is returning to his duty at West Point— George went Accordingly this morning to Boston in the Stage— I wrote a short Letter by him to his mother. Mr Withington came about nine O’Clock; and we went and surveyed the remainder of my father’s Salt-marsh. First a Lot of Acres called the Coves lot, otherwise the Pine Island Creek lot— Our company this Morning, were my brother, Mr Withington, My Son John, Deacon Savile, Ordway one of my father’s workmen, and my Servant William Poet— This first lot though large was easily taken, there being no question, about the boundaries— We then went down, beyond the Mount Wollaston farm, near Germantown, and surveyed the last lot of Salt-marsh, being Acres purchased of Peter Turner as Administrator upon the Estate of my uncle Peter Boylston Adams— I call it the Moschito-gate lot; it being very near that place, and those insects being more thick and annoying there than I ever witnessed any where else. It was all but insupportable and we gladly returned home— I found Mr John Appleton of Cambridge, had called upon me as a visitor; and as usual to make enquiries concerning his Son, who is now going as Chargé d’Affaires to Sweden— He was here about an hour, and in the meantime Mr Withington with his company commenced the Survey of Stoney-field Hill—the portion of the farming lying South of the Road and opposite to the house— Deacon Savile had left us, after the Pine-Island creek was completed— After Mr Appleton was gone, I joined Mr Withington’s party; we finished about half that part of the farm, and returned to dine at 2 O’Clock— At 3. immediately after dinner we resumed the Survey, and perambulated that part of the farm, commencing the circle from East to West, until near Sunset, when it was completed. Mr Withington engaged to come again on Thursday, should the weather be fair— This day has been one of the most sultry of the Summer. The thermometer above 80—the Sun great part of the day intensely burning, and the Moschito—appaling. I know not that I ever underwent a more fatiguing day— Yet I was occupied the Evening till past ten—writing. My brother and my Son John did not go with us after dinner; but Farrar went with Ordway, and William Poet to carry the Chain.
23. V. Beclouded— Quincy—Boston— Quincy.

I went to Boston, with my Son John to attend the Visitation of the Schools— I called for a few minutes at the Exchange Hotel, and thence in a Carriage to the Adams School in Mason Street near the West end of West Street— On the way I met in School Street my Son George who was immediately going in the Stage to Worcester— To be overtaken there to-morrow morning by his Cousin T. B. who is to go in a Stage that departs at two in the Morning. At the School we found the Mayor, Alderman Thomas Welsh, and some members of the School Committee. They were engaged in the examination of the boys in Geography, which was followed by Questions upon the rules of arithmetic; the performance of several sums of practice in the rule of three— Then by reading several extracts, in prose and verse, from a compilation recently made and published— Then two or three Specimens of good Declamation— An exhibition of the writing Books, and of several Samples of writing— All good none very superior— The mayor then distributed the medals awarded to the most deserving of the boys, but observed that the Committee had at that School had some difficulty in assigning the Prizes, from the great equality of the performances— He observed also that there was some deficiency found in the examinations of Geography and the Rules of Arithmetic at this School, which was attributed to the absence of the Master for several weeks by indisposition— We thence went to the High School, a recent institution, where the higher mathematics are taught without the languages— The examination here was in Geometry, in the Roots and Powers; in the simple equations of Algebra, and in what they call mental Arithmetic, the immediate performance of compound multiplication and division without pen or pencil—paper or slate— There was one declamation here, but the Mayor was obliged by the pressure of Time, without waiting for the distribution of the prizes there to hurry to the Latin School—where there was construed by the boys part of the third Satire of Juvenal, and the Ode to Mercury of Horace. Then various Declamations in English, Latin, Greek Verse and Prose, and the distribution of the Prizes by Mr Gould the Master. We then walked in procession, after the boys, to Faneuil-Hall, where was a dinner of about 300 persons among whom, sixty of the boys who took the prizes— Nine regular Toasts in quick succession after dinner— After which Volunteers at the first of which I addressed the company: and soon after left them— Sir Isaac Coffin, N. Biddle, W. W. Seaton, and President Kirkland were of the Company. I returned to the Hotel, where T. B. Adams took leave of us, and we got home about 9. P.M.
24. V:15. Cloudy— Surveying Wood-lots— Rain.

The weather this Morning was of threatening and equivocal appearance; but Mr Withington came, and we proceeded to the survey of two Woodlots; called the Joy and Furnace lots— My brother, my Son John, Farrar, Ordway, and William Poet, went with us, and Mr James Hall who was owner of neighbouring lots, and is well acquainted with the local sites went with us as a guide— He shewed the boundaries, the bearings and courses of which were taken by Mr Withington— We were upwards of five hours, traversing the woods; climbing rocks, wading through Swamps, and breaking through the brakes— It was literally a tangled forest, and before we got through discouraged my brother and my Son John, so that they strongly intimated they should go no more upon such Service— On the ledge, close by that where the Rail-way corporation are at work, Farrar discovered three Snakes, two of which he killed, and George John brought them home as Trophies— They were what our Men called bastard Rattlesnakes; half-breeds between that Reptile, and the Water Snake; but they had no rattles; nor a tail formed ever to have any— They were about three feet long, and four inches in circumference— We were told that yesterday the workmen at the Railway had killed a Rattlesnake with ten Rattles, which came within a few feet of where they were working. It began to rain soon after we got into the woods, and continued until we came home, though moderately— Mr Withington went home directly from the ground promising to come again on Saturday—if the day should be fair; but inclining rather to wait till Monday, for the next day’s labour. It was past three O’Clock before we got home, and the Ladies of the family had dined. My brother, my Son John and I dined together— In the afternoon and Evening, I wrote to Mr Brent of the Department of State, and in this Journal. It rained almost the whole of the afternoon and Evening; so that we were confined to the House— There were invitations came by a special messenger, from President Kirkland; to attend the Commencement next Wednesday; and the Boylston Prize-speaking the next day; and then to dine with him— He wrote me also that unless prevented he should to visit me to-morrow— The large Potatoe-worm found on the step of the door on the 18th. this morning, after three days of a nearly torpid state, cast his skin, just as the other Sphinx had done, and became a green nymph or pupa; which was gradually blackening the whole day. We have now several, which in various ways have gone into the Chrysalis condition.
25. V. Rain

Rain all Night, and this whole day with so little intermission that I could not snatch an hour for exercise out of the house— At the dusk of Evening there appeared to be an interval, and I sallied forth for a walk—but was within ten minutes was driven back by Moschito’s swarming in the air, which was itself damp & dense, almost to the consistency of Rain— I passed the day and Evening writing—without Tediousness, but without clearing off my budget of unanswered Letters— It is the Stone of Sisyphus— The more heavily I roll it uphill, the more precipitately it sweeps down again— I answered two Letters from the Secretary of War—wrote one to Mr Colman of Salem, to whom I send a copy of my Mother’s Letter of 15 January 1780. to me; and began a Letter to Mr Rush upon the inexhaustible case of Edward Thomson’s Teas. But this I did not finish and am so dissatisfied with what I have written, that I must write it over again— I am fearful that this weather will render it impossible for me to accomplish my purpose of attending personally at the Surveys of all the Lands belonging to my fathers Estate, and which are to be sold. This is the twentieth day since the Sun rose clear Two thirds of that time has been drenched with incessant rains— The chain men yesterday waded over their knees through a swamp, which in ordinary times at this Season would have been dry; and this is the period of the year when the Rattlesnakes and other venomous Serpents are most dreaded and dangerous— My motives in having the Surveys made were to ascertain the boundaries, which have long been uncertain of much of my father’s Lands, and in attending myself to have a knowledge of them which I never possessed— Had the weather been as it almost always is at this time of the year, dry, there would have been little difficulty; but the proper times for surveying these Lands would be in April or May with the first drought, before the heat of Summer, or in September and October, in the clear cool drought of Autumn; or in the Winter, with the ground and swamps hard frozen, and covered with a thin Coat of Snow. If I am obliged to leave the Surveys incomplete, the Sales cannot be made before my return to Washington, and all the arrangements for the Execution of the Will must remain unfinished.
26. V. Cloud. Mist— Walk to the old Mill-Pond. 1. hour.

There being a cessation of rain this morning I took the opportunity for an hours walk, and stop’d and spoke to John Briesler by the way. Dr Kirkland and Mr Gray came as a Committee from the Corporation of the University, to request my attendance next Wednesday at Commencement, when they proposed to receive me in form, and the President to Address me— I told him that I had just answered his obliging invitations for Wednesday and Thursday, and regretted that I was obliged to decline both— Expecting to be engaged the whole of next week upon indispensable business. Observing also that I had received invitations to attend at the Commencements of Bowdoin College in Maine, and at Princeton, both of which I should decline, I thought a public reception at Cambridge now, might be considered as a mark of partiality to my own Alma Mater, which even if justifiable might give some offence— Next year, or at some other Time, I hoped it would be more in my power to accept the proffered kindness of the Corporation— In this he acquiesced— Mrs Willard my next visitant is the keeper of a female Seminary of Education at Troy in New-York— About a week since I received a Letter from her, urging the expediency that Congress should patronize an institution for female education, with a small pamphlet published by her, recommending the same subject to the Legislature of New-York— Mrs Willard is a sensible and spirited woman, and I told her that her purpose of improving female education, had my approbation and hearty good wishes; and with regard to any assistance from Congress I was sorry she must expect nothing more— Congress I was convinced would now do nothing— They will do nothing for the education of boys, excepting to make Soldiers; they will not endow an University— I hoped this disposition would change; but while it continues, any application to Congress for female education must be fruitless— Mrs Willard thanked me for the frankness with which I had spoken, which she said she preferred to the delusive flattery with which her sex were usually treated, and after some intelligent discourse on female education, took leave. Mr Marston dined and spent the Evening with us— My Son John and Mrs Clarke went into Boston before dinner and returned in the Evening— Mrs Storer aged 91. died yesterday— I Bathed at Mr Greenleaf’s wharf this afternoon. He was here this morning; returned the appraised inventory, and lent me the plans of my father’s donations in the Town.
27. V. Cloud— Fog— Mist.

Heard Mr Walker of Charlestown, in the morning from Romans 2.15 “Which shew the work of the law, written in their hearts, their Conscience also bearing witness, and their thoughts the mean while accusing or else excusing one another”— In the afternoon from Psalm 34:8 “O taste and see that the Lord is good.”— Both these Discourses were argumentative, and that appears to be Mr Walker’s turn of mind. The drift of the Morning Sermon was to shew, that Conscience is not sufficient to restrain men from crimes, unless aided with the belief and fear of retribution hereafter— In that of the afternoon was a warm exhortation to deserve the divine favour, and share in its blessed fruits— There were passages of Eloquence in both, and a picture of the death bed of a sinner tortured by remorse of Conscience drawn with vigour and coloured with Address— But there is a stiffness of manner in the delivery which marks the whole School of Unitarian Clergymen in this neighbourhood, and of which Mr Walker has too much— He came home and dined with us— I asked him some questions concerning the two Thomas Shephards who were successively Ministers at Charlestown, and Daniel Quincy. He had already examined the Church and Town Records at my father’s request without success— Mr Fay is the Minister of the first Congregational Society at Charlestown, and has the old Records— Towards Evening I called at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s— He shewed me in his orchard near the house a humming bird’s nest, with two young ones in it just fledged. They filled the nest which had scarcely room for them— On my lifting my finger over them at two or three inches distance, they took flight, and one of them alighted on a neighbouring tree— The other fell into the grass and was taken up and restored to the nest by Price Greenleaf. They were full grown, and about the size of an English walnut— Mr. G. W. Beale, and Miss Wayles came in while I was at Mr Greenleaf’s. Mrs Greenleaf is confined to her chamber with a Cold. I answered this day, several Letters from the Secretary of the Treasury; chiefly concerning the questions, which have arisen from Edward Thomson’s frauds upon the public revenue—
28. V.— Fog. Mist— Walk round to the Canal brook. Rain

This Mr Adams, lives in Roxbury and is the Son of the late Elijah Adams of Medfield, the compiler of the family genealogy— He was here some weeks since, and I made some enquiries of him concerning the second Henry Adams, which he was not able to answer— He now brought me an Extract from the Town Records of Medfield from which it appears that at the first Settlement of that Town, about 1650. he removed to it from Braintree, and was there as he had been at Braintree the first Town-Clerk— The names and dates of birth of four Sons born to him there, and Elizabeth his wife, are on the minute, and that he died in 1675— One of this Mr C. J. Adams’s objects in calling upon me this morning, was also to say that he was desirous of obtaining some place in the Custom-house at Boston— I told him I would mention his name to the Collector— This morning my wife quite unexpectedly arrived here, with Elizabeth C. Adams, Thomas J. Hellen, and the maid servant Jane Winnull. Mrs Adams left Lebanon Springs last Wednesday the 23d.— The very day that George left Boston to meet her there— That same morning she received my Letter of the 17th. proposing to meet her at Mr Boylston’s at Princetown. She proceeded nevertheless through Hudson and Poughkeepsie to New-York, where she arrived on Saturday Morning— Meeting there Thomas J. Hellen, who was returning from Washington, to the University at Cambridge, she concluded to come here with him; but sent the Carriage and Horses back to Washington, where our Son Charles also went— She came in the Steam-Boat from New-York to Providence, and arrived last Evening at Boston— Mr. Gorham and Mr Gray came to pay a morning visit. Mr Withington, came and took the Survey of the lands round the house; and re-measured a part of the ground, on the Southern side of the Road in which an error had been committed last Tuesday— He was anxious to have the other Surveys of the Woodlands postponed till late in the Autumn; but in that case there could be no settlement of the Estate, before my return to Washington. I desired him to come the first settled fair day, and said we would proceed and Survey as far as we could— Stopping wherever we may find it impracticable to go on— This day like twenty which have preceded it was Sultry, with fog, mist and frequent showers of Rain— I walked round by the Canal brook, before breakfast, hunted by Moschito’s, and was confined to the house the remainder of the day. Wrote two or three short Letters, and signed 75 Land-grants.
29. IV:30.— Clear warm day.

My brother’swife and Mrs Clarke went early this morning into Boston, and took in with them George Foster, a young son of Phineas Foster, who is at the Latin School in Boston, and being now in vacation has been spending some days here with his Cousins. I received a Letter from Benjamin Russell, Editor of the Centinel at Boston, asking for a copy of my Address to the company at Faneuil Hall, last Wednesday—which I accordingly made and sent him— My wife and my son John, with Thomas J. Hellen went into Boston after breakfast, and returned this Evening— They took my brother’s youngest Son Joseph with them— They had previously bathed at the Beach, and I alone at the wharf— Mr Daniel Greenleaf called, and informed me that Captain Bass and Deacon Adams would be at his House on Friday Morning when they proposed to go and view as much as they could of the real Estate that was my fathers, to appraise it— I am very apprehensive that a part of the woodlands must be left unsurveyed for the present—owing to the swelling of the waters in the Swamps by the late heavy rains— I wrote two or three short Letters, and otherwise till my hand and shoulder refused their Offices— Mrs Swett and Mrs Bartlett acquaintances of my brother’s wife were here this afternoon; but she being absent they made a short visit— At the dusk of Evening I walked to Mr Whitney’s, and took back with me the most recent of his Books of Records— He was himself absent, at Cambridge to attend the dedication of a new building for a theological Institution— His son George is with him, and is to reside for some time as a graduate; to pursue his theological studies there. The weather has this day been fair, and the sky clear; but warm, and with a scorching Sun— The long succession of wet and sultry weather has multiplied the insects, particularly moschitos to a degree, beyond any thing that I ever knew any where. It has driven me back many times, from Evening and Morning walks and even from short visits to the garden— I find indeed no difficulty in occupying all my time within doors— The business of the Public follows me here— The Settlement of my father’s affairs, hangs a heavy weight upon me— Domestic concerns of my own and my brother’s family, are full of perplexity, and my genealogical researches, my plants, worms and butterflies fill the vacuity of time, till I loathe the bustle and turmoil of political life, and long for permanent repose.
30. IV:— Fair day. Survey of Wood lots.

Mr Withington the Surveyor came about eight this morning and we resumed the Survey of the Wood-lots, belonging to my father’s Estate— Our party this day, besides the Surveyor were, my brother— David Porter Harmon, Ordway, Farrar, and my man Servant William Pote. Porter and Harmon are woodsmen, heretofore employed by my father to cut wood upon his lots for the consumption of his family— Porter is an old man 74 years of age, having lost an eye, and infirm in health— Harmon a man of about 45. in full vigour and perfectly acquainted with these woods— Two lots were surveyed—one called the Quincy, Beale & Savil lot, and the other the Adams lot, being one given by my Grandfather in his Will, to my father and my Uncle Peter Boylston in common and subsequently divided between them— We entered the woods about 9 O’Clock in the morning, and came out of them between five and six in the afternoon. We traversed a continual thicket of Woods, four fifths at least of which consisted of Oaks—White, Black, Gray, Chesnut, and Scrub— With these were intermingled, White, and Pitch Pine, red Cedar, Hemlock, Chesnut, Black Beach, Bass Wood, (American Lime of Michaux) Shellbark and pignut hickory, Black Birch, yellow Ash, Sassafras, Witch-Hazel, and several others, which neither I nor any of the company knew— With these were brambles and briars, barberry bushes, blackberry vines, many creeping vines, plants and mosses, of which we were all ignorant— Of the animal creation, I took no account. We started several pheasants and a covey of quails— Saw an hawk hovering over a precipitous ledge of rocks at least 200 feet high which we ascended—heard occasionally the croak of the crow, and the scream of the blue Jay— We descended into deep vallies and crossed running brooks about half-leg deep, and ascended upon ledges of rocks whence the town and the harbour of Boston, alive with all its navigation, and the spines of all the neighbouring villages were in prospect around us. About 2 O’Clock we took a delicious repast of slices of corned beef, bread and cheese, apples and pears with Rum, wine, Cider and water— My dress was light and succinct, and better prepared, for the tangles of the forest, and against both moschitos and the possible chances of Snakes than last week— I was however in a continual stream of perspiration, nearly the whole day, and constantly annoyed by the insects— We stop’d sometime on our return at Mr Porter’s— This was Commencement day— John and Thomas Hellen went into Boston. My wife very unwell. Mrs Quincy, with her daughters Susan and Abigail, and G. W. Beale here this Evening.
31. IV. Before day-light— Survey of Wood-lots— Fair day.

We continued the Survey of the Woodlots— Mr Withington came, and we started about 9. A.M. turned up at the lane opposite to Arnold’s, just beyond the old ninth Mile Stone, and entered the fields a few rods beyond David Porter’s House— We were engaged part of the morning in correcting an error made yesterday—our company now being, with the Surveyor, my brother, Harmon, Elijah Spear, Farrar, Ordway, and William Pote, my servant man— Spear left us after the survey was completed of the lot with the bounds of which he was acquainted. That is about noon— The Survey of the last Lots called Borlands being 25 acres we could not complete, the line running through a Swamp so deepened by the late rains that although William and Farrar waded nearly half their depth into it, Mr Withington could not get all the lines for it— The day was passed much the same as yesterday; but this day we returned and took our dinner, which was precisely similar to that of yesterday, at the place where we had left our horses and carriages— We went forth again however after dinner, and completed all that can be done by Mr Withington— The only bounds which mark the lines between the lots of different individuals are small heaps of Stones placed in certain directions by the Compass— We returned home about six in the Evening, and in coming from the fields turned to the right and came round by the old mill-pond, and the Meeting House— I pursued this day as far as I was able, the enquiry concerning trees and plants, but with little more than the conviction, that weeks, months and years would be necessary to obtain an accurate knowledge of even the plants which cover the surface of the grounds we have traversed I confined my attention to the trees and shrubs principally— To the Oaks mentioned yesterday are to be added, the Red-Oak, the Sycamore or Button wood, the American Poplar, and White Birch— The Poke-Berry, Brake, and Fern, with the poisonous Ivy, and yet more poisonous dogwood— And there were yet many herbs, plants and vegetations from the earth of which no one could tell the names. When I returned home I found, Mr Morton and Mr Homer from Connecticut, asking for a subscription. Mr Kilborn Whitman afterwards called— Ruth Turner, and Miss Boardman were here at tea with the young Ladies— My wife was quite ill, and was attended by Dr Holbrook— My Son John and T. B. Hellen had returned from Boston.
